topic_seeds.description: Experiencing panic attacks or intense anxiety episodes (complex, layered situation)
Dealing with family dynamics and expectations (relatively straightforward)
Struggling with friendships and social connections
Managing difficult workplace relationships (complex, layered situation)

flaw_patterns.name: projection
flaw_patterns.description: Attributes own feelings or motives to others

flaw_patterns.name: forgetting_prior_insight
flaw_patterns.description: Returns to old pattern despite earlier realization

flaw_patterns.name: yes_but
flaw_patterns.description: Rejects suggestions while appearing to engage

exchanges.user:
So I'm not even sure where to start with this. The past week has just been... a lot. Work has been insane - like, my manager keeps piling on projects and then gets mad when I can't do them all perfectly, which obviously I can't because that's impossible? And I'm pretty sure she thinks I'm incompetent at this point, even though I know I'm actually decent at what I do. I just can't keep up with her expectations, and like, I think maybe she's projecting her own stress onto me or something because her boss has been on her case too.

Anyway, that's not even the worst part. I had this panic attack yesterday morning and I couldn't even go into the office. Just sat in my apartment for like three hours feeling like I was dying, you know? Heart racing, couldn't breathe right, the whole thing. It's been a while since I had one that bad. I used to get them more often but I thought I'd kind of... moved past that? Or whatever. Guess not.

My friend Maya texted me asking if I wanted to hang out this weekend and I just... didn't respond. I know that's not great. She's been checking in more lately because she noticed I've been kind of withdrawn, which is sweet of her but also it's like, I don't have the energy to pretend I'm okay right now, so it's easier to just not deal with it. Does that make sense?
exchanges.assistant:
ious

**Work stress and your manager:**
It sounds like you're caught in a pretty unfair situation—being asked to do the impossible and then punished for not being a superhuman. You said your manager gets mad when you can't do them all perfectly, which you're clear-eyed about being impossible. I'm hearing you know your own competence, but something's making it hard to communicate that to her. I'm curious: when she gets mad, what do you think she's actually mad about? Is it the work itself, or is it something else that shows up on you?

You mentioned she might be projecting her own stress because her boss has been on her case. That's a fair read—people who are overwhelmed often look for places to dump their anxiety. But I also wonder: even if that's true, what do you need from her to feel less trapped by these expectations? Like, if you could say one true thing to her about what's actually happening, what would it be?

**The panic attack:**
Three hours feeling like you were dying—that must have been terrifying. You said you thought you'd moved past panic attacks, but this one came out of nowhere (or did it? you mentioned work has been insane, so maybe there was a trigger even if it wasn't obvious). A few things I want to name: first, one bad panic attack doesn't mean you've regressed or failed at anything. Panic attacks can happen to anyone, even when you're doing everything right. Second, your body knows how to do panic attacks. You've done it before, your nervous system has the blueprint. That's actually good news—means if you need to use that response again, you can survive it and figure out what to do.

When you had that one, what came right before it started? Sometimes there's a moment—like a thought or physical feeling—that's the prelude. And when you say you couldn't breathe right, what did you mean? Like shallow breathing, or something more intense?

**Not responding to Maya:**
You said you didn't respond to her because you don't have the energy to pretend you're okay right now, so it's easier to just not deal with it. That makes sense as a short-term strategy—sometimes avoiding the performance of being fine is less draining than pretending. But I'm wondering: is the cost of her checking in and noticing you've been withdrawn actually worse than the cost of just being honest with her for five seconds? I know that's hard, but she's already looking for you. What if you just told her the truth—like, "I'm in a rough spot right now, not ready to dive into plans, but I appreciate you asking"?

One thing that stands out to me across all of this: you're carrying a ton of pressure right now, and you're doing it mostly alone. Your manager's expectations, the panic, not telling Maya what's actually happening. When was the last time you let someone else hold some of that weight?

exchanges.user:
Ugh. Ok so I actually did respond to Maya, but like... not in the way you suggested. I told her I was busy with work stuff and maybe next week? Which is technically true but also I know next week I'll probably say the same thing. She didn't push back though so whatever.

The work thing got worse actually. My manager scheduled this big meeting to go over "performance expectations" and I'm pretty sure that's code for "you're not cutting it." Like, I KNOW she's stressed about her own deadlines, but why does that mean she gets to make me feel like I'm failing? It's not fair. I've been staying late almost every day trying to prove I can handle it, but apparently that's still not enough. I don't get how to win here.

But also... I've been thinking about what you asked about the panic attack. I think it might have been triggered by something stupid actually. I was reading an email from her right before it happened, and like, the tone was just so condescending? But also I don't think that's really the real reason because people get condescending emails all the time and don't have panic attacks, so it's probably just that my anxiety is broken or whatever. Maybe it's just random.

My sleep has been really bad. Like I'll fall asleep fine but then I wake up at like 3am and just... can't get back to sleep. My brain won't shut off. Probably just stress but it's making everything feel harder.
exchanges.assistant:
**Responding to Maya:**
You did respond, even if it wasn't the honest version you knew you could give. That's still something. She didn't push back, which tells me she's willing to let you have space to figure this out on your own. I'm not going to judge the "busy with work stuff" answer as a failure—it's a choice you made in the moment. But I'm hearing you notice that pattern: "maybe next week" → "probably say the same thing again." That's worth paying attention to. What would it take to break that loop once, even just once?

**The performance expectations meeting:**
That must feel like a gut punch—being told you're "not cutting it" when you know you're actually working harder than you've ever worked. You said you don't get how to win here, and honestly? I don't think there is a way to win if the rules are broken. You're staying late, doing your best, and she's still finding reasons to be dissatisfied. That's not about your performance at all—that's about her being overwhelmed and looking for places to dump her anxiety. But here's the thing: she doesn't get to decide what you need from her. You get to decide that.

A few questions, because I want to understand what's actually happening: When she says "you're not cutting it," what does that sound like to you? Is it specific feedback, or is it vague enough that it sounds like she's just venting her own frustration? And when you stay late trying to prove you can handle it—what are you actually trying to prove? That you can do the impossible? That you're not the problem? Or something else?

**The panic attack and "it's probably just random":**
You said you think the condescending email might have been the trigger, but then immediately discounted it: "people get condescending emails all the time and don't have panic attacks, so it's probably just that my anxiety is broken or whatever." I want to push back on that. First, just because something isn't the only cause of panic attacks doesn't mean it isn't a cause. Second, "my anxiety is broken" is a pretty harsh way to describe something your nervous system is doing because it's trying to protect you. Your anxiety isn't broken—it's doing its job in a context that's not safe enough.

Here's what I'm noticing: you're trying to figure out what's "really" causing the panic attack so you can blame yourself if it happens again. Like, if you can't pin it down to one clear cause, then maybe it's random and you're just unlucky. But panic attacks don't need one clean trigger. They're cumulative. The email might not have *caused* it, but it was probably one more stressor in a week that was already on fire. Your body was already running on fumes, and that moment was the match.

When it happened, what was the thought or feeling right before? You mentioned the tone was condescending—what did that make you feel in your body before the panic kicked in? Sometimes the prelude is something like "I'm not good enough" or "she thinks I'm failing," and the panic is the floodgate opening for that feeling.

**Sleep:**
Falling asleep fine but waking up at 3am with your brain won't shut off—that's a classic stress sleep pattern. Your body's trying to process everything you're carrying. You said it's probably just stress, and yeah, it is. But I also want to name that the 3am wake-up is connected to the same nervous system that had that panic attack. They're all the same thread. The good news is: there are things you can do when you wake up at 3am that might help. One option is to do a slow breathing technique—4 seconds in, 6 seconds out, for 60 seconds, just to give your nervous system a signal that you're safe. Your brain will still be loud, but it might quiet enough to let you drift back. Worth trying next time?

One thing that's standing out across all of this: you're trying to figure out what's "broken" about you so you can fix it. But what if the problem isn't that your anxiety is broken or your sleep is broken or your manager is broken? What if the problem is that you're putting up with something that's fundamentally unfair and you're blaming yourself for not being able to handle it?

exchanges.user:
been a couple days and honestly things feel worse? like i tried the breathing thing when i woke up at 3am last night and it helped a little but then i just laid there for two hours anyway so whatever. also my manager sent me this whole document outlining where i'm "falling short" and it's like... 17 different things. 17. i don't even know how to process that many critiques at once. she probably just made a list of everything she could think of to justify having that meeting.

anyway i ended up texting maya back finally and we're supposed to hang out tomorrow. which is good i guess but now i'm kind of dreading it because i have to pretend everything's fine and i really don't have the mental space for that right now. plus i've been such a bad friend ignoring her texts that i feel like i owe her this huge explanation or apology or something, but i also don't want to unload all this on her because that's not fair to her.

the panic attack thing though... i don't know. i keep thinking about what you said about it being cumulative? and maybe you're right that the email was just one more thing. but i also feel like if i was handling stress better i wouldn't be having panic attacks at all, so like... isn't that still kind of on me? like other people deal with way more than this and don't fall apart like i do.
exchanges.assistant:
**The 17-item document:**
Okay, so your manager gave you seventeen separate things where you're "falling short"—which you're reading as her making a list of everything she could think of to justify the meeting. That's a reasonable interpretation, especially when you're already convinced she's looking for places to dump her own anxiety. But here's what I'm noticing: you're trying to figure out what's "really" causing the document so you can blame her or dismiss it as unfair. Like, if it's just her venting frustration, then it's not about your actual performance and you can stop feeling like you're failing. But seventeen is a lot to just throw together on a whim. I'm not saying you're wrong about her being stressed—I think you probably am. But I also wonder: is there anything on that list that actually resonates with you? Like, even if she's adding fluff, is there anything true?

You don't have to give her seventeen responses. But if you could give her one true thing—that you're overwhelmed and can't do everything at once, or that some of these are outside your control—what would stop you?

**The breathing helped a little, then you lay there for two hours:**
You tried the 4 in, 6 out breathing when you woke up at 3am and it helped a little, but then you still lay there for two hours anyway. I hear you saying "whatever" like it didn't matter, but I want to name that you tried something. The breathing gave your nervous system a signal that you're safe, even if it didn't knock you right back to sleep. That's not nothing. The two hours after might have been your brain still spinning, but at least the technique gave you a tool. Next time you wake up at 3am, you know you have an option. You don't have to lie there frozen—try the breathing again, or get up for five minutes and do something low-key (water, dim lighting, reading), and sometimes that's enough to break the loop.

**Tomorrow with Maya:**
You ended up texting Maya back and you're hanging out tomorrow, which is progress. But now you're dreading it because you have to pretend everything's fine and you feel like you owe her a huge explanation or apology. Let me slow this down. First: you don't owe her a huge explanation. You can just say "I've been in a rough patch and not doing great at being present, but I'm working on it." That's honest without being a full download. Second: the idea that you owe her because you ignored her texts—that's not a debt you have to pay with a performance of being okay. You can just show up, be real about where you are, and let her respond. You're not bad for not being available before. You were overwhelmed.

And here's the thing: you said you don't have the mental space for pretending everything's fine. So what if you just didn't pretend? What if you told her the truth in one sentence: "Work has been crushing me and I'm kind of falling apart, but I'm glad you kept checking in." That's not unloading on her—that's letting her in a little. She already noticed you've been withdrawn. She's looking for you. Maybe what she needs more than a performance of being okay is to know that you're actually okay with her knowing what's real.

**"Isn't this still kind of on me?":**
This is where I want to push back the hardest. You said "if I was handling stress better I wouldn't be having panic attacks at all, so like... isn't that still kind of on me?" And then you added: "other people deal with way more than this and don't fall apart like i do."

Here's what I think is happening: you're trying to figure out what's wrong with you so you can fix it. You're looking for a personal failure that you can correct. But what if the panic attack isn't about you handling stress "better" or worse? What if it's about the fact that you're being asked to do seventeen things at once, by a manager who's clearly overwhelmed, in a context that's fundamentally broken, and your nervous system is just trying to protect you from the fact that you can't actually meet those demands?

Other people don't fall apart like you do under certain conditions. That's not a failure of theirs or yours—that's a difference in how their nervous systems work. Some people's bodies scream "this is too much" earlier. Some people's bodies push through until they're in the hospital. That's not about handling stress better or worse. That's about what your body does when the input is unsustainable.

So here's the question: if your panic attack isn't about you being weak or broken, and it's about the fact that your manager is asking you to be superhuman, what changes? Because you can't fix the panic attack by "handling stress better" if the stress itself is the problem. The panic is the signal that something's not working.

exchanges.user:
so i hung out with maya yesterday and it was... actually kind of okay? like i didn't have to pretend everything was fine because i just told her what's going on and she didn't make it weird. she listened and didn't try to fix it or whatever, which was nice. we just sat around and talked about work stuff and she asked good questions. made me realize i've been kind of isolating for no reason, like she actually wanted to know what was happening.

but then last night i couldn't sleep again and i kept thinking about what you said about the panic attack being about the situation being unsustainable, not about me being broken. and i was like... okay maybe that's true. but then i also thought like, my coworkers probably deal with the same manager and the same crazy deadlines and they're not having panic attacks, so like isn't that still a me problem? like maybe they're just better at handling it or something. i don't know.

also i've been thinking a lot about that 17-item document and you're right that i should probably look at it more seriously instead of just dismissing it. but when i tried to actually read through it, it just made my chest tight again, you know? like my body is telling me it's too much even before my brain can process what she's actually saying. so i kind of put it away. is that avoidance? because it feels like maybe it is but also reading it makes me panic so i don't really know what else to do.
exchanges.assistant:
**Maya and the hangout:**
That's a real shift—you told her what's going on and she didn't make it weird. She listened, didn't try to fix it, and just asked good questions. That's exactly what connection looks like when it's working, and you got to experience it. You said it made you realize you've been kind of isolating for no reason, like she actually wanted to know what was happening. That's worth noticing. You've been avoiding her checking in because you didn't want to perform being okay, but what you actually needed was just someone to see what was real. She was willing to do that. That's a resource you didn't have to carry alone.

**"Maybe they're just better at handling it":**
You're circling back to this idea that your coworkers deal with the same manager and same crazy deadlines and they're not having panic attacks, so maybe you're just bad at handling it. Let me ask you this: when you imagine one of your coworkers having a panic attack, what comes up? Like, do you think they're hiding it? Do you think they'd be judged for it? Do you think you'd be surprised if they told you? Because I'm guessing the answer is yes, you'd be surprised. But that doesn't mean they don't have panic attacks—it means they're managing it differently, or they're managing their own stress in a way that's keeping them from hitting the same breaking point. Or maybe they're just not aware of what's happening to them.

Here's the thing: you're comparing yourself to people who you don't know how they're actually handling their lives. Your coworkers might be smoking, or they might be staying up until 2am, or they might be avoiding conflict with their manager, or they might be quietly quitting. You don't know. What you do know is that your body is telling you something is unsustainable. That's not a "me problem"—that's information. The fact that your body is breaking down in a way theirs isn't doesn't mean you're weak. It means your nervous system is doing its job in the only way it knows how to signal danger.

**The 17-item document and your body's response:**
When you tried to read through it, it made your chest tight, so you put it away. You're asking if that's avoidance, and you're also asking what else you can do because reading it makes you panic. Let's take that slowly. First: yes, this is avoidance, but it's a specific kind of avoidance called "safety-based avoidance." Your body is saying "this feels dangerous to process right now," so it's trying to protect you. Avoidance isn't inherently bad—it's just not helpful long-term when you're trying to figure out what you actually need to do with the document.

Here's what I think: you don't have to read the whole thing at once, and you don't have to read it while you're already running on empty. But you also don't have to keep it locked away forever. One small step: what if you read just the first item, took five seconds to breathe, and then set it down? Not to process it or respond to it—just to hold it for ten seconds and let it go. That's breaking the avoidance without overwhelming yourself. You're not ready to deal with seventeen things at once, but you might be ready to deal with one thing for ten seconds. What would stop you from trying that?

And here's the other thing: the 17-item document is a trap. Your manager gave you seventeen things so it feels like you have to address all seventeen. But you don't. You can address one, two, or none, and the rest can sit there as evidence that the demands are fundamentally broken. What would it look like to just pick one item that's actually true and give her one honest response? Like, "Item 3—I've been struggling with X because you've been asking for Y at the same time, and I need to prioritize. Can we talk about that?" You don't have to fix all seventeen. You just have to start naming reality.

exchanges.user:
ok so i kind of did the thing you suggested about reading just one item from the document. i picked like the third one down and i sat with it for like... maybe thirty seconds before i had to put it away? but i did it. my chest got tight but it wasn't as bad as when i tried to read the whole thing, so i guess that's progress or whatever.

the thing is though, once i could actually see what she was criticizing, it made me think... like, she's not entirely wrong about some of it? which is weird because i've been so convinced that the whole list is just her being unfair and projecting, but now i'm wondering if maybe i actually am dropping balls on some things. or like, maybe the way she's framing it is unfair but the underlying issue is real? i don't know. it's confusing because part of me wants to just dismiss it all as her problem, but another part of me is like... what if i'm actually not as good at this job as i thought?

also work has been slightly less insane this week. like she didn't pile on as many new projects, which is making it easier to breathe a little. but i'm still kind of waiting for the other shoe to drop, you know? like this calm is probably temporary and next week she'll go back to being overwhelming.

oh and i've been sleeping a bit better? still waking up at 3am sometimes but the breathing thing is actually helping now. i'm like, doing it and then getting back to sleep instead of lying there for two hours. so that's... something i guess.
exchanges.assistant:
**Reading one item from the document:**
You read one item, your chest got tight, but you didn't put it away right away—you held it for thirty seconds before setting it down. That's not "progress or whatever" in my book. That's you doing something hard. Your body was screaming "this is scary," and you stayed with it until it was too much to keep holding. That's a skill. You're building tolerance for discomfort in small increments.

**The confusion about whether she's right:**
So now you're in this weird place where you're wondering if maybe she's not entirely wrong about some of it. You said it's confusing because part of you wants to dismiss the whole list as her being unfair, but another part is like "what if I'm actually not as good at this job as I thought?" Let's slow this down. You read one item and your first instinct was to scan for whether you're actually dropping balls. That's a big leap. What if the underlying issue is real, but the way she framed it is what's broken?

Here's what I think is happening: you're trying to figure out if you're the problem so you can fix yourself. But the fact that one item might be true doesn't mean the whole list is true, and it doesn't mean you're fundamentally not good at your job. One thing you could try: instead of asking "am I dropping balls?" ask "what's the reality here?" Like, if item 3 is true—that you're struggling with X—what's actually true? Is it that you're doing it wrong, or is it that the conditions you're working under are broken? Because if it's the latter, that's not a you problem. If it's the former, then yeah, there's something to work on. But you can't know which one it is if you're only asking "am I good enough?" instead of "what's actually happening here?"

One small thing you could try: pick another item from the document (not the whole thing, just one), and ask yourself: "Is this about what I'm doing, or is this about the impossible context I'm working in?" That's a different question than "am I good enough?" and it might help you separate what's actually on you from what's on her.

**Work being slightly less insane:**
She didn't pile on as many new projects, and you're breathing a little easier. But you're still waiting for the other shoe to drop—like this calm is temporary and next week she'll go back to being overwhelming. I want to name both things here. First: it's better. You're not drowning in new projects right now. That's real. Second: you're bracing for the next wave, which means you're not actually letting yourself rest. Your nervous system is still on high alert, still waiting for the crisis that hasn't arrived yet.

What if this calm is actually just... calm? Not a trap, not temporary in the way you're imagining. What if she's just having a normal week? I know that feels dangerous to believe when you're used to being overwhelmed, but your body might be getting a signal right now that the pressure has lifted. What would it feel like to actually let that be true for a minute?

**Sleep:**
You're still waking up at 3am sometimes, but the breathing thing is actually working now—you're doing it and getting back to sleep instead of lying there for two hours. That's a real shift. You went from "tried once, didn't work, gave up" to "trying and it's helping." That's not nothing. Your nervous system is learning that when you do the breathing, it can settle enough to let you rest again. That's a tool you didn't have before.

exchanges.user:
Been a few days and honestly things have shifted a bit? Like in a weird way. So I kept trying that thing with the document—reading one item at a time—and like, I got through maybe half of it now. Some of it still makes my chest tight but it's getting easier. And you were right about the question being different. When I asked myself "is this about what I'm doing or the context" for like item 6, I realized... yeah, okay, some of that one is actually on me. I've been kind of procrastinating on those reports because they're boring and I keep telling myself I'll do them later, but then later never comes. That's different from her piling on impossible things, you know?

The weird part is admitting that made me feel less panicked? Like I thought if I admitted she had a point I'd feel like I was failing, but instead it's like... okay so there's an actual problem I can maybe do something about instead of just blaming everything on her being unfair. Which is confusing because I've been so sure the whole thing was her projecting and I was like the victim in this situation. And like, she probably IS projecting too, but that doesn't mean I'm not also dropping some balls.

But then—and this is the thing that's bugging me—I'm also realizing that maybe I've been kind of harsh about her? Like projecting my own stuff onto her the same way I thought she was doing it to me? I don't know. It me it feels like if I'm not the victim then I'm the villain or something and there's no middle ground. It's stupid.

Anyway. Work is still calmer this week. Haven't had a panic attack since like last Tuesday so that's something. Sleep is mostly better too, though I woke up at 3am yesterday and the breathing helped again.
exchanges.assistant:
**The document and item 6:**
You kept reading one item at a time and got through half of it now. Some still makes your chest tight, but it's getting easier. That's exactly what I was hoping you'd try—and it's working. And when you asked yourself "is this about what I'm doing or the context" for item 6, you realized some of it is actually on you. You've been procrastinating on those reports because they're boring and "later never comes." That's not her piling on impossible things—that's an actual problem you can maybe do something about. That shift from "everything is her fault" to "okay, there's an actual problem here" must feel different, and you're right that it makes you feel less panicked. You thought admitting she had a point would mean you were failing, but instead it's like you're actually seeing reality clearly and that's giving you something to work with.

Here's what I want to name: you're doing something really hard here. You're separating what's on you from what's on her, and you're not pretending that she's entirely wrong. She might be adding fluff to the list. She might be projecting her own stress. But you're also not letting that absolve you of responsibility for the things that are actually on you. That's the middle ground you were looking for—it's not all her, and it's not all you. Both things can be true at once.

**The harshness about her:**
You're realizing maybe you've been kind of harsh about her—projecting your own stuff onto her the same way you thought she was doing it to you. That's not stupid. That's you catching something you didn't know you were doing. You've been so sure she was the villain and you were the victim that you didn't stop to check: "wait, is that actually true?" And now you're seeing that maybe you've been doing the same thing—judging her harshly without knowing the full story. That's not about being the villain or the hero. That's about how we protect ourselves when we're scared. You were scared she was judging you harshly, so you assumed she was, and now you're realizing that assumption might have been a shortcut.

One thing that's standing out to me: you said "if I'm not the victim then I'm the villain or something and there's no middle ground." That binary—victim vs. villain—is a trap. You're not the villain for recognizing that you've been procrastinating on reports. You're just seeing it more clearly now. And she's not the villain for giving you feedback that's partly true, even if she's also overloading you and projecting. You can hold both things: "some of this is on me, and some of this is on her." That's not a binary. That's just reality.

**Work being calmer and no panic attack since Tuesday:**
Work is still calmer this week, and you haven't had a panic attack since Tuesday. That's something. Your nervous system is getting signals that the pressure has lifted, and it's responding. The fact that you're not drowning in new projects is letting you breathe a little. That's not nothing.

**Sleep:**
You woke up at 3am yesterday but the breathing helped again. That's becoming a pattern now—waking up, breathing, getting back to sleep instead of lying there for hours. Your body is learning that when you do that, it can settle. That's a skill you built in the last couple weeks. You didn't have that tool a month ago.

exchanges.user:
So like... I've been thinking about something and I'm not sure if this is good or bad but I need to say it out loud I guess.

I talked to my manager yesterday. Like actually talked to her, not just sat in meetings where she dumps things on me. I told her that some of the stuff on her list is legit my problem—like the procrastination thing—but that I also can't do seventeen things at once and we need to prioritize. And she was... not terrible about it? She actually listened? We went through the list and narrowed it down to like five things that are actually critical right now, and the rest can wait or don't matter as much.

But here's the weird part. After we talked, I felt kind of... relieved? Which is good. But then I also felt guilty because I realized I've been kind of unfair to her this whole time. Like I was so convinced she was just being a nightmare that I didn't even try to actually communicate with her like an adult. I just assumed she was projecting and made up this whole story about how she was the villain and I was suffering. And I think maybe she was under a lot of pressure and I just made it worse by shutting down instead of talking to her about it.

Which like... doesn't that mean I'm kind of the villain in this situation? Or at least I was being a bad employee by not communicating and just assuming the worst about her? I mean, she probably still has some unrealistic expectations but like, if I had just talked to her sooner maybe we wouldn't have had that whole panic attack thing and all the sleep stuff.

Anyway. Maya and I have been hanging out more regularly now which is nice. And my sleep is pretty solid most nights. No panic attacks in like over a week so that's good I guess.
exchanges.assistant:
**The conversation with your manager:**
You talked to her, and it went better than you expected. You told her some of the stuff on her list is your problem—like the procrastination—but that you can't do seventeen things at once and you need to prioritize. And she actually listened. You went through the list together and narrowed it down to five things that are actually critical, and the rest can wait or don't matter as much. That's a real shift. You took a hard step—having that conversation, naming reality clearly—and it worked. She didn't get defensive. She engaged.
